title: Isaiah’s Entrapment Parable of the Vineyard
html:
Isaiah presents new literary techniques and teaching patterns in this unusual chapter. Using a parable with a surprise ending, six snapshots of woeful human behavior, and a prophecy with a pleasant promise, he foreshadows the scattering of the children of Israel, recounts their multiple disappointments, and foretells their eventual gathering. This chapter divides easily into three sections: the parable of the vineyard (vv. 1–7), a series of six pronouncements upon wicked Israel (vv. 8–25), and a promise of an ensign that will rally a great latter-day army (vv. 26–30). In each of these sections, Isaiah follows a threefold pattern:

1. Calling upon an audience and identifying their high hopes.

2. Describing the Lord’s dealings with them.

3. Highlighting how the outcome of events is contrary to earlier expectations.

This pattern of high expectation, clarification, and low fulfillment appears several times throughout the chapter.
